page.title: 04ORAL HISTORY
page.content: Mr Harry Barber,77 was born and bred in the village. He remembers Balderton as a pleasant rural spot with many green fields. There were at least ten farms and Main Street was often crowded with animals being taken to Newark market. He recalls the pen in Pinfold Lane where stray animals were kept until being claimed by their owners. Next to the John Hunt School was the Wash Dyke which gave drovers the chance to wash their cattle. It was from the Cock Inn that the horse bus departed. Another bus left from Milton Street. The large houses in Balderton owned by the brewing and brick making families often opened their gardens to the public, and many charities benefitted from the money raised. Little vandalism existed at the time.
